content: The "Intersection in one point" validator contains two circles *not* intersecting at any point at all. The title is misleading.
I have a javascript working solution with a formula instead of testing all points :p I approve
The right word is disk, a circle is a line.
I don't know which term is preferred in English :/

Indeed, updated the input of that test from:
2 2 2
2 8 2

to:
2 2 2
2 6 2

That way both circle intersect in a single point at the coordinates (2, 4)

I've just reformatted the Input section.

Original version:
<<Line 1 :>> [[x1 y1 r1]]. x1 and y1 determine the position of the center of the first disk, and r1 its radius
<<Line 2 :>> [[x2 y2 r2]]. x2 and y2 determine the position of the center of the second disk, and r2 its radius

Reformatted version:
<<Line 1 :>> Three space-separated integers [[x1]], [[y1]] and [[r1]]. [[x1]] and [[y1]] determine the position of the center of the first disk, and [[r1]] its radius
<<Line 2 :>> Three space-separated integers [[x2]], [[y2]] and [[r2]]. [[x2]] and [[y2]] determine the position of the center of the second disk, and [[r2]] its radius

Also, if you don't mind, I'd like to propose adding five new pairs of cases. It turns out that some solutions (including my original one) can pass the current tests and validators while still producing incorrect results for certain scenarios.

I'm unable to add these cases because (if I understand correctly) your Java solution uses a sampling-based method to approximate the answer, whereas my results rely on the exact formula. Would you please review this and see what can be done?

Details of the new cases:

Thanks.

Hi 5DN1L,
Indeed the Java solution doesn't seem to be working well on your test cases, where the approximation is not good enough (I'm assuming your proposed results are indeed the right ones).

The purpose of thise puzzle was to accept monte carlo based solutions (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monte_Carlo_method), which is a "think out of the box" solution instead of focusing on the maths formula that would provided the very best output.

Should we reduce the available range of x1, x2, y1, y1, r1 and r2?
Like -100 to 100 to x and y coordinatates and 1 to 100 for r?

Obviously finding the right formulas is the best, and might be quite easy doing AI these days.
However being able to find a side solution that actually provides a good approximation is really what I wanted to highlight with this puzzle, to showcase that "good enough is the ennemy of the best" => because the puzzle doesn't ask you to provide the best solution, but to give a good approximation, then it's okay to find approximative solution.

Hi Amendil,

Sure! That's a great idea. Your original objective and solution can be kept, and the updates to the existing puzzle are kept minimal, while new cases can be added to provide better coverage.

Below are the required adjustments to the existing puzzle:

Constraints
* 1st constraint: change -1000 to -100.

* Both constraints: change 1000 to 100.

Cases
* The last pair of existing cases can be updated as follows:

One in another 1
(Add "1" to the name, since "2" will be used for the new cases)

5 5 80
20106.19
